video.title: Django Tutorial - Create a Digital Resume with a Python Backend
video.description:
Improve your Django skills by building a digital resume website. You are provided a free resume template and you will learn how to create the backend using Django and Python.

✏️ Course from Bobby Stearman. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCitbHjDxcR3JBErnRLCuYkw

💻 Template: https://github.com/bobby-didcoding/didcoding_resume_template
💻 Django Code: https://github.com/bobby-didcoding/resume_app

⌨️ (00:00) Intro 
⌨️ (01:28) Select template 
⌨️ (03:28) Start django project 
⌨️ (05:57) Backend 
⌨️ (44:06) Frontend 

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Wong Voon jinq
👾 hexploitation
👾 Katia Moran
👾 BlckPhantom
👾 Nick Raker
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster
👾 AppWrite

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Did Coding
topLevelComment.text: Thanks for posting this tutorial. I had a lot of fun putting it together. If I can help one developer get their dream job then I’ll chalk that down as a win 😀

topLevelComment.author: Dmitriy Nayanov
topLevelComment.text:
If you don't see skills, do two things:
1. find in index.html a string "<div class="progressCard">" and two strings below change "{% if sk.is_key_skill %}" to "{% if not sk.is_key_skill %}" (condition "not" is needed here)
2. In admin panel in your user profile select all the skills holding down a key Ctrl, press Save
Enjoy :)

replies.author: Linda Lu
replies.text: @Joseph Segbefia Thank you! I solved the same problem according to your solution. For mine, the skills box must remain unselected. And the "if not" works. I tried delete if loop, just keep the content, it also works.

replies.author: eoin vaughan
replies.text: @Joseph Segbefia Awesome, found it thanks to you. New to this so getting my head around how all the pieces fit together and talk to each other. Very interesting stuff.

replies.author: Joseph Segbefia
replies.text: @eoin vaughan in the index.html file. Under the h4 tag with the text coding skills  there is a for loop and under the for loop there is an if statement. That is the one i am referring to.

replies.author: eoin vaughan
replies.text: @Joseph Segbefia if statement where? which file are you referencing?

replies.author: Joseph Segbefia
replies.text: I had the same problem, I realised that in the admin section under user profiles, all skills present in the skills box must remain selected to get rendered on the front end. An on the front end under the coding skills section,  and within the if statement add the word 'not' right after the 'if'. It should work from now on.

replies.author: cain abel
replies.text:
@D Israel 

Good questions, the first two questions I would answer "yes". I believe in both self-improvement as well as learning new ideas and concepts. 

To answer you final question I have a schedule in which I follow to make sure I get the things I want to get done. Mine you it is not a todo list I took a masterclass from a guy from MIndvalley who stated that TOO list are not the way to go.

You can see a short 3 mins intro

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N2aSKmV6obg

replies.author: D Israel
cain abel
replies.text:
@D Israel 

Most people would say to make money but for me I love learning, I love learning about all sort of things new technologies, old technologies,  software, hardware, history, poetry, cooking,  English literature, math, languages,  drawing, etc, but I do not learn these things to lord it over someone but rather to acquire knowledge in order to improve myself.  It is hard to quantify the hunger I feel when it comes to learning and acquiring knowledge, most people do not understand the need I feel to learn, to acquire knowledge not for money but for the sake of knowledge itself.

To answer you question my motivation for learning to code is because I find it extremely interesting, the way lines of characters come together in order to create a piece of a software,  as a by product if I were to make money out of it then great if not then I still okay with it.

  I am at around 1:19:19 mark because they were certain things that did not work and I had to do a little bit of research in order to get it to work.

replies.author: D Israel
replies.text:
@cain abel what's your motivation to learn coding? Is to make a lot of money , or you just find it all interesting?
P.s. did you follow this whole 1;22;22 tutorial?

topLevelComment.author: Kaustubh Jadhav
topLevelComment.text: How to create virtual environment like that?

replies.author: Aditya Parida
replies.text:
You have to install virtualenv using pip command then create virtual environment using command "virtualenv venv", then go inside the script folder which is inside the venv folder to activate virtual environment.  
Note: instead of venv you can use any name for that.

replies.author: Ahbar Ahad
replies.text: I haven't watched the video but I'm guessing you are asking about how to generate a virtual environment for python projects, the answer is: "venv" or "pipenv"

topLevelComment.author: TECH IN 5 MINUTES
topLevelComment.text: Django is interesting because it has stable ways of working with some modules. You can choose them when you need them, saving you a lot of time, money, and effort, getting all the solutions right out of the box.

replies.author: Raikumar Khangembam
replies.text:
Yes, it saves time because of built in the admin panel. So far we created 5 to 7 projects. Clients have been using that with no complaint. 
Previous 3 years ago I used PHP and its framework laravel and slim. It needed to create an admin panel separately from scratch.
